snippet: Rent-stabilized leases amount to a public benefit, just like disability or unemployment benefits, officials argue, and thus cannot be seized as an asset in a personal bankruptcy.
abstract: New York City and state officials are joining effort to help 79-year-old Mary Veronica Santiago keep her rent-stabilized lease from becoming asset with which to pay off her creditors; file friend of the court brief saying that lease is not property that can be sold and that it undermines safeguards that both bankruptcy and rent laws are supposed to provide.
lead_paragraph: Rent-stabilized leases amount to a public benefit, just like disability or unemployment benefits, officials argue, and thus cannot be seized as an asset in a personal bankruptcy.

headline.main: New York State and City Join Effort to Shield Stabilized Leases
headline.print_headline: State and City Join Effort to Shield Stabilized Leases
